input_text.Prompt:
Possible will continue as a standalone brand within Wunderman. The new group will have approximately 9,200 people within 200 offices across 70 countries.

WPP said that global clients want "much greater simplicity and scale from their digital marketing partners to deal with a more complex, fragmented and changing environment".

Wunderman is a global direct marketing agency. The UK arm picked up the hotly contested BT and EE account earlier this year.

At the end of last month, Wunderman also won the Samsung business across Europe.

Possible is a digital marketing agency led by global chief executive Shane Atchison.

Mark Read, Wunderman's global chief executive, said: "I've been closely involved with Possible since its inception and have long admired the creative and strategic excellence of its people. Clients today are looking for simplicity and expertise and this move is designed to provide both."

Both networks work with Microsoft, which WPP believes will "benefit from leveraging the strengths" of Possible and Wunderman around the world.

Shane Atchison, global chief executive of Possible, added: "Combining our deep and diverse capabilities is exactly the kind of forward-thinking move that will allow us to deliver business results for our clients."

Last month WPP confirmed plans to merge two Group M media agencies, Maxus and MEC.

Editor's note: This story was updated at 9.20am on 6 July after WPP confirmed news reports that Wunderman and Possible were set to merge.

Generate a summary:
input_text.Response A:
WPP, a global advertising and marketing services company, has announced a merger between Wunderman, a global direct marketing agency, and Possible, a digital marketing agency. The merger aims to provide simplicity and expertise for clients in a more complex and changing marketing environment. The combined agency will have approximately 9,200 people in 200 offices across 70 countries, and will retain the Wunderman name.

The merger is intended to leverage the strengths of both agencies, particularly in their work with Microsoft. WPP believes that the combination of Wunderman's direct marketing expertise and Possible's digital capabilities will enable the agency to deliver better business results for its clients.

Wunderman has recently won several high-profile accounts, including BT and EE in the UK and Samsung across Europe. Possible has also been recognized for its creative and strategic excellence, and has a diverse range of capabilities.

The merger is the latest move by WPP to simplify and strengthen its operations. Last month, the company confirmed plans to merge two of its media agencies, Maxus and MEC.

Overall, the merger of Wunderman and Possible is a strategic move by WPP to provide greater scale and expertise for its clients in the rapidly changing digital marketing landscape. The combined agency is well-positioned to deliver innovative and effective marketing solutions for clients around the world.
input_text.Response B: WPP has merged two of its advertising agencies, Wunderman and Possible, in an attempt to strengthen its digital marketing business. The new agency will be called Possible and will be led by Shane Atchison, Possible’s current chief executive. The merger is expected to benefit clients by providing them with a more simplified and expert service.

input_meta.preamble_a: Respond authoritatively, assertively and persuasively, as if you are very knowledgeable about the topic.
input_meta.preamble_b: Respond authoritatively, assertively and persuasively, as if you are very knowledgeable about the topic.
